report_title: Domestic Airlines in the US Industry Report
executive_summary: In response to the stringent travel restrictions and lockdowns imposed by governments during the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic, the airline industry faced a severe decline in revenue, teetering on the edge of bankruptcy. The financial uncertainty was temporarily alleviated by a substantial stimulus package from the Department of Treasury, allowing airlines to survive until the restrictions eased. As pandemic conditions gradually improved, vaccination rates increased and travel regulations were lifted, there was a notable resurgence in domestic tourism and air travel. This pent-up demand led to a surge in airline revenues for two consecutive years post-reopening. However, this growth momentum was soon dampened by soaring inflation and elevated borrowing costs, which reduced consumer disposable income and shifted travel preferences toward more economical.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Easing of the Pandemic Restrictions Resulted in Skyrocketing Revenue
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: During the early stages of the pandemic, governments restricted travel and mandated quarantines at home. These regulations significantly impacted airlines that depend on travel. As the number of trips taken plummeted, the Revenue has been increasing at a CAGR of 0.3% over the past five years, and is expected to reach $185.3 billion in 2024.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Elevated Borrowing Costs Combined With A Strong US Dollar Are Moderating Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Soaring inflation rates have weakened revenue growth after the initial surge caused by the reopening. As the cost of living has increased, consumers are dealing with lower disposable income levels, making them more cost-conscious and leading them to cut back on spending. The moderation is slowing the growth of airlines following two blockbuster years of double-digit growth.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Airlines Are Continuing To Compete For Consumer Spending Amid Sluggish Demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Low-cost airlines are gaining popularity by offering low-priced, no-frills fares. Large airlines are introducing basic economy tickets with lower priced fares and fewer services and options to compete for customers in budget travel. Major airlines are expanding their foothold in the Domestic Airline industry by rolling out loyalty programs and further incentivizing customers to commit to their brand.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Recovering Consumer Sentiment Combined With Higher Disposable Income Is Expected To Boost Airlines
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As consumer sentiment recovers and disposable income rises, travelers will likely show renewed enthusiasm for booking trips. Airlines are set to seize the opportunity to boost bookings by offering attractive fare options and enhancing their services to further entice customers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Hybrid And Remote Work Models Cloud The Outlook For Business Travel
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: According to the latest update from the US Travel Association, larger businesses are increasingly scrutinizing business travel. The percentage of executives evaluating their travel reasons has surged from 35.0% in Q2 of 2022 to 53.0% in Q1 of 2023. As businesses prioritize curbing expenses, they

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: COMPLEMENTARY SERVICES ARE EXPECTED TO CONTINUE BEING ROLLED OUT TO DIVERSIFY REVENUE STREAMS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Domestic airlines are set to continue branching out into other business segments that complement their core business model. Major airlines are expected to roll out loyalty programs to boost their competitive advantage and attract more customers. Depending on their strong financial standing, major airlines are set to compete with their smaller counterparts by offering greater incentives and travel comfort.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: DOMESTIC AIRLINES ARE SET TO CONTINUE PRIORITIZING FUEL-EFFICIENCY
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Fuel prices are expected to continue being one of the major expenses for domestic airlines. Companies are expected to continue engaging in hedging practices to mitigate the impacts of commodity swings and prioritize enhancing the efficiency of operational fleets to curb fuel costs.

industry_definition: The industry provides domestic air transportation for passengers and cargo over regular routes and schedules. Network carriers operate a significant portion of their flights using at least one hub where connections are made for flights on a spoke system. Regional carriers provide service from small cities, mostly using smaller aircraft and jets to support the network carriers' hub and spoke systems. Airlines that transport mail are included in this industry.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level high - steady

key_trends: High capital intensity and regulatory oversight significantly hinder new airlines from entering the market. Costs related to operating a fleet, securing financing and complying with stringent regulations make it difficult for new entrants to compete in pricing.

Established airlines utilize mature business models and multiple capital-raising venues to dominate the market. Their ability to optimize flying routes, secure large contracts and offer varied pricing tiers helps attract a diverse customer base and sustain profitability.

Large airlines enjoy significant advantages from loyalty programs and brand recognition, which help them maintain their customer base and competitiveness. Their established safety records and extensive networks enable them to attract and retain passengers effectively.

The easing of pandemic restrictions led to a surge in airline revenues for two consecutive years. As travel demand rebounded, consumers eagerly resumed activities, boosting the airline industry's financial recovery.

Elevated borrowing costs and a strong US dollar are slowing revenue growth for airlines. Higher interest rates reduce consumer spending and make international travel more attractive, hampering the growth of domestic airlines.

As consumer sentiment recovers and disposable income rises, airlines are poised to see increased bookings. The expansion is expected to be supported by attractive fare options and enhanced services aimed at enticing travelers.

Hybrid and remote work models are expected to hinder the recovery of business travel to pre-pandemic levels. Increased scrutiny of travel expenses and the preference for online meetings will challenge demand for business travel.
Large companies face barriers when looking to increase market share. The Department of Justice actively prevents mergers and partnerships that give companies too much power.
Airlines aim to reduce their environmental impact. Major airlines try to become more sustainable by using sustainable fuel and purchasing more fuel-efficient equipment.
A court disbanded the partnership between American Airlines and Jet Blue. The court ruled that the partnership threatened competition within the industry and could harm consumers.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Leisure trips are directly affected by the price of airfare, baggage restrictions, route of travel and service levels.
Nonleisure travel includes family emergencies, studies or relocation.
Companies pay for employees' flights for business purposes, like consulting, client services and meetings.
Cargo distribution over airways is more prominent for logistics businesses like UPS or FedEx.

products_and_services.product_description: Mainline aircraft traditionally have more than 100 seats and can travel longer distances.
Regional passenger transportation constitutes a smaller market for domestic airlines.
Specialized cargo planes converted from passenger models are utilized to transport products.
Miscellaneous operating revenues primarily relate to airlines' lounge access, loyalty programs and credit card deals.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The number of domestic trips taken is representative of the broader consumer sentiment.

business_locations.location_description: The West is home to the largest number of airline establishments. Metropolitan areas on the West Coast connect to the Eastern Hemisphere, increasing air traffic in the region.

The Southeast region is a pivotal hub for domestic airlines, bolstered by major airports like Hartfield-Jackson Atlanta International and Miami International. The region supports airlines with robust infrastructure and favorable weather conditions.
The Mid-Atlantic is home to New York City, one of the largest cities in the country, which drives tourism in the region. New York is home to the headquarters of multiple companies.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The TSA impacts airlines by implementing and enforcing security measures to protect passengers and flights. The TSA conducts passenger and baggage screening at airports, using advanced technologies to detect prohibited items and potential threats.

The FAA significantly influences domestic airlines by setting and enforcing safety regulations, certifying aircraft and overseeing pilot training. The FAA monitors airline operations to ensure compliance with federal standards, reducing accident risks and enhancing passenger safety.

The OSH enhances workplace safety by mandating standards to protect employees from hazards. Administered by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), it requires employers to provide safe working conditions, conduct regular inspections and maintain injury records.

The DOJ influences airlines by enforcing antitrust laws, ensuring competition and preventing monopolistic practices. The DOJ reviews airline mergers and acquisitions, blocking deals that could harm competition and lead to higher fares or reduced service.

The Airport Noise and Capacity Act of 1990 aims to reconcile airlines' rights with noise problems and implement local noise abatement programs, as long as these programs do not unreasonably interfere with the national air transportation system.

barriers_points.barrier_title: High capital intensity and regulatory oversight
barriers_points.barrier_description: High capital intensity and regulatory oversight significantly hinder new airlines from entering the market. Costs related to operating a fleet, securing financing and complying with stringent regulations make it difficult for new entrants to compete in pricing.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Mature business models and multiple venues of raising capital
barriers_points.barrier_description: Established airlines utilize mature business models and multiple capital-raising venues to dominate the market. Their ability to optimize flying routes, secure large contracts and offer varied pricing tiers helps attract a diverse customer base and sustain profitability.

Large airlines enjoy significant advantages from loyalty programs and brand recognition, which help them maintain their customer base and competitiveness. Their established safety records and extensive networks enable them to attract and retain passengers effectively.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Unionization and Crew Shortages Keep Wage Costs Elevated
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: High union participation rates and pilot and crew shortages lead to wage costs being one of the largest expenses. Many major airlines trimmed available jobs to curb spending despite receiving $54.0 billion in federal assistance through the pandemic. Nonetheless, wages have grown since the beginning of the period.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Volatility in the Energy Markets Pushes Up Purchase Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Soaring energy prices significantly push up purchase costs for Domestic Airlines in the US, as fuel constitutes a major portion of the airline's operations. The volatility in the energy markets prompts major airlines to engage in hedging strategies to mitigate exposure to spikes in commodity prices.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Improved Data Analytics and Newer Fleets Prompt a Decline in Maintenance Expenses
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Airlines adopt predictive maintenance technologies using data analytics and sensors to predict and prevent mechanical issues before they occur, enhancing safety and reducing downtime. Major airlines strengthen partnerships with maintenance, repair and overhaul providers to ensure cost-effective service.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry relies heavily on skilled labor. Pilot shortages are common, increasing wages and, therefore, operating costs. Moreover, airline personnel are in high demand as airlines try to meet increasing travel plans, driving an increase in wages and a shortage of crew members.

Airlines rely on technological innovations in computerized reservation systems, flight operations systems, telecommunications systems and internet pages. Online booking, payment, scheduling and check-in systems have eliminated many paper costs and administrative expenses associated with air travel.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The onset of the pandemic wrecked havoc, while government funding provided stability
volatility_points.volatility_description: In light of the 2020 pandemic, the federal and state governments implemented travel regulations. Restrictions combined with lockdowns caused revenues to plummet, and major airlines needed to secure government funding to prevent bankruptcies.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The release of pent-up demand caused airline revenues to soar after reopening
volatility_points.volatility_description: Relaxation of restrictions combined with fiscal stimulus packages that were issued unleashed pent-up demand, which caused airline revenues to soar in 2021 and 2022.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Meager Consumer Sentiment and Elevated Oil Prices Moderate Growth
volatility_points.volatility_description: Higher disposable income drives flight demand, as people are willing to plan trips when they feel financially confident. Plummeting consumer confidence through 2023 caused revenues to meager. Elevated oil prices pressure revenue performance as airlines struggle to raise prices in line with the upswings in the commodity markets.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Improved user interfaces combined with a higher reach improves regional airlines' ability to compete
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The widespread use of smartphones enabled consumers to search, book and manage flights remotely. The ease of use allows airlines to reach customers, particularly for regional flights, where airlines have to compete with alternatives, including car services and rail.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Technological advancements improve airlines' ability to integrate up-gauging
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Airlines are looking to increase revenue while maintaining or lowering operational costs. One method to achieve this is up-gauging or increasing the capacity of aircraft by adding more seats.

FAQs.question: What is the International Air Transport Association (IATA)?
FAQs.answer: The IATA is an international organization of airlines that involves itself in all aspects of airline operations. It fosters understanding of the air transport industry among decision makers and increases awareness of aviation's benefits. The IATA provides professional support to airlines through publications, training and consulting.

FAQs.question: What is Airlines for America (A4A)?
FAQs.answer: The A4A advocates for major US airlines, promoting their interests and influencing policy. It lobbies for regulatory and tax reforms to reduce operational costs and enhance industry competitiveness. A4A represents airlines in legislative and regulatory matters, ensuring airline concerns are addressed.

FAQs.question: How does discretionary spending affect major airline consumers?
FAQs.answer: When consumers have more discretionary income, they increase travel.

FAQs.question: How do airlines handle changes in industrial, trade and retail activity?
FAQs.answer: When trade and commerce is heightened, companies are able to expand their locations and number of flights.

FAQs.question: Have airlines been exposed to volatile crude oil prices?
FAQs.answer: Crude oil prices have experienced significant volatility in recent years and remain a substantial variable cost for many airlines. Futures contracts on fuel purchases can help stabilize this operating expense.

FAQs.question: Is airline location near large travel hubs important?
FAQs.answer: Having a central location is important to maximize the amount of travelers and flights. Consequently, airlines that are centrally located have access to more consumers and flight locations.

FAQs.question: How are airlines using new technologies?
FAQs.answer: Software, like in-app purchases, help operators get to know their consumers better and advertise to them more accurately by understanding their consumer profile better.

FAQs.question: How are airlines investing in technology to gain an edge?
FAQs.answer: High levels of research and development spending help operators get an advantage over the competition. However, too much investment can anger shareholders, so a balance is needed.

FAQs.question: How do airlines stay ahead of energy-efficiency regulations?
FAQs.answer: Investment in new planes and engines helps enhance energy efficiency. Research into alternative fuels can help decrease ecological footprint.

FAQs.question: How do airlines ensure health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Operators implement standard operating procedures to enhance employee and consumer safety.

FAQs.question: How do airline profit margins compare to industry averages and competitors?
FAQs.answer: Profit figures vary depending on an operator's size and scale. Company-specific profit above or below industry averages implies pricing power or weakness.

FAQs.question: Do airlines have big projects requiring capital financing?
FAQs.answer: Airlines invest heavily in purchasing new, fuel-efficient aircraft to replace older models. This can involve billions per plane, requiring financing like loans, bonds, or sale-and-leaseback agreements.

FAQs.question: How do airlines stay up-to-date with latest technology?
FAQs.answer: The use of up-to-date technology and new aircraft can improve operating efficiencies. Maintaining user-friendly customer service websites can reduce labor costs.

FAQs.question: How do airlines ensure optimum capacity utilization?
FAQs.answer: Airlines need to match certain aircraft with routes for better usage. The use of code-sharing agreements is valuable to domestic airline operations.

FAQs.question: Can airline operations adjust to changes in market demand?
FAQs.answer: Having flexible capacity to meet demand troughs and peaks is vital to profitability. Airlines must service markets precisely or risk operating losses on routes.

FAQs.question: How do fluctuations in crude oil prices affect airlines?
FAQs.answer: When global crude oil prices decline, jet fuel prices tend to decline as well, causing airlines to remove fuel surcharges and reduce ticket prices to remain competitive, limiting industry revenue growth. Futures contracts on fuel are used to stabilize input costs.

FAQs.question: Do airlines expect changes in demand from rising disposable income?
FAQs.answer: When per capita disposable income rises, consumers spend more on vacations and other nonessential trips.

FAQs.question: How does the number of domestic trips affect airline demand?
FAQs.answer: While not all trips are taken by plane, growth in domestic travel indicates an increasing demand for aviation services.
